user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of version:
```c
static int version(void)
{
	char ver_def[16], ver_dyn[16];

	snprintf(ver_def, sizeof(ver_def), "%d.%d.%d",
		 METAL_VER_MAJOR,
		 METAL_VER_MINOR,
		 METAL_VER_PATCH);

	snprintf(ver_dyn, sizeof(ver_dyn), "%d.%d.%d",
		 metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch());

	return (strcmp(ver_def, METAL_VER) +
		strcmp(ver_dyn, metal_ver()));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function version:
#define METAL_VER_MAJOR 1
...
#define METAL_VER_MINOR 8
...
#define METAL_VER_PATCH 0
...
#define METAL_VER "1.8.0"
...
int metal_ver_major(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MAJOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_minor(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MINOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_patch(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_PATCH;
}
...
const char *metal_ver(void)
{
	return METAL_VER;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the uses of functions that read or write string objects need investigation for potential out-of-bounds access. The fragments above include the buffer declarations, the two formatted writes that populate those buffers, and the two strcmp calls that read them — these interactions should be checked to ensure no read past the buffers' bounds. Other code in the submission does not require investigation for Rule 21.17: the macro definitions (METAL_VER and the numeric macros) are compile-time constants and METAL_VER is a null-terminated string literal; the helper functions metal_ver_major/minor/patch simply return those constants; there are no other calls to <string.h> functions in the provided code. Therefore no additional fragments need to be reported.
